to the inn,<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del1"/>leaving the shore we sought the retreat of our house and garden. <del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del1"/>but<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del1"/><del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del2"/>a<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del2"/>Again as I entered the iron gates of the demesne, an <del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del3"/>unres<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del3"/> unexplainable feeling bade me hold—yet Elizabeth <pb n="117"/>unwarned, and fearless passed on, and I, again half ashamed—& for the first time dreading lest any unholy sight should meet her sense, any shadow of the fiend, should cross her, <del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del4"/>I<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del4"/> hastily walked on, and passing my arm round her prayed with a feeling of bitter tenderness, that she might never suffer ill. Thus we entered the <del sID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del5"/>ar<del eID="novel1_letter4_chapter22_del5"/> mansion—and still not speaking, for both our hearts were too full, we went
